passage:
(1) The Reformation, a religious revolution that swept across Europe in the 16th century, fundamentally altered the landscape of Western Christianity and European society. This momentous period of religious upheaval began in 1517 when Martin Luther, a German monk and professor, published his Ninety-Five Theses criticizing practices of the Roman Catholic Church, particularly the selling of indulgences. Luther's actions, facilitated by the recently invented printing press, sparked a movement that quickly spread beyond Germany, leading to the emergence of Protestant denominations and challenging the religious unity that had prevailed in Western Europe for centuries.

(2) While theological debates formed the core of the Reformation, its causes were multifaceted. Social discontent with clerical wealth and corruption had been growing, while the Renaissance had fostered intellectual currents that emphasized returning to original sources, including the Bible. Political rulers often supported reform movements to gain independence from papal authority and to seize church properties. Additionally, the emerging merchant class was attracted to Protestant teachings that seemed more compatible with commercial activities. Together, these factors created fertile ground for Luther's ideas to take root and flourish.

(3) The Reformation quickly diversified as reformers with different theological perspectives emerged. In Switzerland, Huldrych Zwingli and later John Calvin developed reformed traditions that were more radical than Luther's approach. The English Reformation followed a unique path, driven initially by King Henry VIII's desire to annul his marriage rather than by theological concerns. Anabaptists advocated for adult baptism and complete separation of church and state, while the Counter-Reformation saw the Catholic Church implement internal reforms and vigorously oppose Protestant movements. This diversity of reform movements resulted in a fragmented religious landscape that replaced the previous Catholic hegemony.

(4) The consequences of the Reformation extended far beyond religion. Bloody conflicts erupted as religious differences became entangled with political ambitions, culminating in the devastating Thirty Years' War (1618-1648). Socially, the Protestant emphasis on individual Bible reading promoted literacy and education. The questioning of religious authority contributed to the development of critical thinking that would later characterize the Enlightenment. Additionally, the Reformation's stress on the

had democratic implications that would influence political developments in subsequent centuries.

(5) The legacy of the Reformation continues to shape the modern world in profound ways. The religious pluralism of contemporary Western society can be traced directly to this period. The emphasis on individual conscience and interpretation created space for concepts of religious freedom that would eventually expand to broader notions of human rights. Educational institutions founded during this era remain influential centers of learning today. Perhaps most significantly, the Reformation established a precedent for challenging established authority that resonates in social and political movements to this day, making it one of history's most consequential episodes of ideological transformation.

questions.question: Choose the correct verb form to complete the sentence: 'If I _____ you, I would accept the job offer.'

options.A: am
options.B: were
options.C: would be
options.D: had been

questions.question: Select the correct passive voice form: 'The committee _____ the proposal yesterday.'

options.A: was discussing
options.B: is discussing
options.C: discussed
options.D: was discussed

questions.question: Which sentence contains a correct use of the present perfect tense?

options.A: She has finished her homework already.
options.B: She finished her homework already.
options.C: She have finished her homework already.
options.D: She will have finished her homework already.

questions.question: Identify the sentence with the correct use of articles:

options.A: He is an university student studying a history.
options.B: He is a university student studying the history.
options.C: He is an university student studying the history.
options.D: He is a university student studying history.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with the correct subject-verb agreement:

options.A: The number of students in the class are increasing.
options.B: The number of students in the class is increasing.
options.C: A number of students in the class is attending.
options.D: Each of the students have their own textbook.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct reported speech: She said, 'I will call you tomorrow.'

options.A: She said that she will call me tomorrow.
options.B: She said that she would call me tomorrow.
options.C: She said that she would call me the next day.
options.D: She said that she will call me the next day.

options.A: who
options.B: which
options.C: whose
options.D: whom

options.C: By next year, I will have been graduated from college.
options.D: By next year, I will have graduated from college.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct use of modals:

options.A: You must to attend the meeting tomorrow.
options.B: You should attending the meeting tomorrow.
options.C: You might to attend the meeting tomorrow.
options.D: You ought to attend the meeting tomorrow.

options.A: If it rains tomorrow, we will have canceled the picnic.
options.B: If it rains tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic.
options.C: If it will rain tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic.
options.D: If it would rain tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic.

questions.question: Identify the sentence with the correct use of gerunds and infinitives:

options.A: She avoided to make eye contact during the interview.
options.B: She avoided making eye contact during the interview.
options.C: She avoided make eye contact during the interview.
options.D: She avoided for making eye contact during the interview.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct comparative form:

options.B: This exercise is the most easiest in the book.
options.C: This exercise is more easy than the previous one.
options.D: This exercise is easier than the previous one.

options.A: She has been working in this company since five years.
options.B: She has been working in this company for five years.
options.C: She has been working in this company during five years.
options.D: She has been working in this company by five years.

options.B: By the time I arrived, the movie has already started.
options.C: By the time I arrived, the movie had already started.
options.D: By the time I arrived, the movie was already started.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct word order:

options.A: Hardly I had finished my homework when the phone rang.
options.B: Hardly had I finished my homework when the phone rang.
options.C: I had hardly finished my homework the phone when rang.

options.B: The recently invented printing press

options.A: Social discontent with clerical corruption

options.C: Desires of political rulers to gain independence from papal authority
options.D: The Black Death epidemic

questions.question: What is the main purpose of this passage?

options.A: To criticize the Catholic Church's practices in the 16th century
options.B: To analyze the political consequences of the Reformation
options.C: To explain the Reformation's causes, diversity, consequences, and legacy
options.D: To compare different Protestant denominations that emerged during the Reformation
